title: Compiler error for improper syntax on trait-bounding lacks proper direction

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: D-confusing
labels.description: Confusing diagnostic error that should be reworked

body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.
-->

I tried this code:

```rust
impl<T> Add<Into<T>> for Sequence {
    type Output = Self;
    fn add(self, rhs: T) -> Self::Output {
      todo!();
    }
}
```

I expected to see this happen:

> Error: Did you mean to implement `Add` over all things that implement `Into<T>`, if so try this `impl<T: Into<u64>> Add<T> for Sequence {`

Instead, this happened: I wrote up what actually happened in a question on StackOverflow, it tells you both the input I got and how I reacted to it: https://stackoverflow.com/q/69264060/124486

### Meta
`rustc --version --verbose`:
```
rustc 1.57.0-nightly (c3c0f80d6 2021-09-14)
binary: rustc
commit-hash: c3c0f80d6081092faff801542dd82f0e2420152b
commit-date: 2021-09-14
host: x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu
release: 1.57.0-nightly
LLVM version: 13.0.0
```
